unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: System Failure
question_text:
A toolmaker fabricates an item that has a system of $4$ O-rings.
Each O-ring has a probability of $0.95$ of properly functioning. Assume that each O-ring operates independently of the others, and the entire system fails if one or more of the O-rings fail.
What is the probability that the system functions properly?
solution:
The problem states that the entire system fails if one or more of the O-rings fail.

This means that all four of the O-rings must function properly. Since the O-rings function independently, we can use the multiplication rule of probability for independent events to calculate the following:
$$\text{P(O-ring working)} = 0.95$$

$$\text{P(4 O-rings working)} = 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95$$

$$\text{P(4 O-rings working)} =0.815$$

An alternate way to solve this problem is to use a binomial probability model, where $n = 4$, $P = 0.95$, and we are interested in calculating the probability that all $4$ of the $4$ O-rings operate properly. On your calculator, use binompdf (4, 0.95, 4) $= 0.815$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
